sans.$description: Primary sans-serif font stack. Use for: all body text, UI labels, form inputs, general content. Public Sans is a neutral, open-source typeface optimized for UI and web. Fallbacks: Helvetica Neue (macOS), Helvetica (older Mac), Arial (Windows/Linux), system sans-serif. LOADING: Include weights 400, 500, 600, 700 for full design system support.

heading.$value: 'Atkinson Hyperlegible Next', 'Atkinson Hyperlegible', 'Public Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
heading.$description: Heading/display font stack optimized for accessibility. Atkinson Hyperlegible Next (by Braille Institute) is designed for maximum legibility, especially for users with low vision. Use for: page titles, section headings, hero text, marketing content. Distinct letterforms reduce character confusion. Falls back to Public Sans for consistency.

mono.$value: ui-monospace, SFMono-Regular, Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, 'Liberation Mono', 'Courier New', monospace
mono.$description: Monospace font stack for code and technical content. Use for: code blocks, inline code, terminal output, data tables with alignment needs, API references. ui-monospace uses system default (SF Mono on Mac, Cascadia on Windows 11). Fallbacks cover all major platforms. All characters have equal width for alignment.

xs.$description: Extra small font size (12px). MINIMUM readable size. Use for: helper text, timestamps, metadata, legal text, footnotes, badge content. Requires high contrast - use with strong foreground colors. Not recommended for primary content. Common in: timestamps, version numbers, copyright notices.

sm.$description: Small font size (14px). Use for: secondary text, table content, form labels, captions, sidebar content. Comfortable for extended reading in UI contexts. Common in: data tables, form labels, navigation items, secondary buttons. Good balance of density and readability.

md.$description: Medium font size (16px). DEFAULT body text size. Use for: primary body text, paragraphs, form inputs, buttons, main content. Browser default - optimal for extended reading. WCAG baseline assumption for contrast calculations. Common in: body text, input values, primary UI text.

lg.$description: Large font size (18px). Use for: lead paragraphs, emphasized body text, large UI elements, card titles. Slightly larger for emphasis without being a heading. Common in: intro paragraphs, feature descriptions, prominent labels, large button text.

xl.$description: Extra large font size (20px). Use for: small headings (h5-h6), subtitle text, section labels, prominent UI elements. Bridges gap between body and heading sizes. Common in: card headings, modal titles, section headers within content.

2xl.$description: 2x large font size (22px). Use for: medium headings (h4), component titles, feature headings. Clearly heading-sized but not dominant. Common in: h4 headings, sidebar section titles, panel headers.

3xl.$description: 3x large font size (26px). Use for: prominent headings (h3), page section titles. Commands attention without overwhelming. Common in: h3 headings, dashboard section titles, feature section headers.

4xl.$description: 4x large font size (34px). Use for: major headings (h1-h2), page titles, hero text. Primary visual hierarchy anchor. Common in: page titles, h1/h2 headings, hero headlines. Pair with lineHeight.xs or lineHeight.sm for tighter leading.

light.$description: Light font weight (300). Use sparingly for: large display text, hero headlines, artistic/elegant contexts, stylized marketing content. CAUTION: Poor readability at small sizes or low contrast. Never use for body text or UI labels. Requires high contrast ratio. Common in: hero text, large quotes, stylized headings.

regular.$description: Regular font weight (400). DEFAULT weight for all body text. Use for: paragraphs, descriptions, general content, form input values, most UI text. Optimized for extended reading. Most content should use this weight. Common in: body text, input values, descriptions, help text.

medium.$description: Medium font weight (500). Use for: subtle emphasis, navigation items, form labels, table headers, slightly prominent UI text. Noticeable but not bold - professional emphasis. Common in: nav items, active states, form labels, table column headers, subheadings.

semibold.$description: Semibold font weight (600). Use for: buttons, important labels, card titles, moderate emphasis headings. Strong emphasis without the heaviness of bold. Common in: button text, card titles, important labels, h4-h6 headings, badge text, tab labels.

bold.$description: Bold font weight (700). Use for: headings (h1-h3), strong emphasis, critical information, maximum text prominence. Reserve for true emphasis - overuse dilutes impact. Common in: h1-h3 headings, alert titles, critical labels, strong inline emphasis (<strong>).

fontWeight.$description: Default font weight for all headings.

fontSize.$description: H1 font size (34px). Use for page titles.

fontWeight.$description: Bold weight (700) for maximum visual hierarchy on page titles.

lineHeight.$description: Tight line height for large headings.

fontSize.$description: H2 font size (26px). Use for section headings.

fontWeight.$description: Bold weight (700) for strong section hierarchy.

lineHeight.$description: Tight line height (1.2) for compact section headings.

fontSize.$description: H3 font size (22px). Use for subsection headings.

fontWeight.$description: Semibold weight (600) for clear subsection emphasis.

lineHeight.$description: Snug line height (1.35) for medium-sized headings.

fontSize.$description: H4 font size (20px). Use for card titles.

fontWeight.$description: Semibold weight (600) for card and component titles.

lineHeight.$description: Snug line height (1.35) for card title readability.

fontSize.$description: H5 font size (18px). Use for small headings.

fontWeight.$description: Semibold weight (600) for minor section emphasis.

lineHeight.$description: Snug line height (1.35) for compact minor headings.

fontSize.$description: H6 font size (16px). Use for label-like headings.

fontWeight.$description: Semibold weight (600) for label-style heading emphasis.

lineHeight.$description: Normal line height (1.5) matching body text rhythm.

tighter.$description: Tighter tracking (-0.05em). Use for: very large display text (48px+), hero headlines, logos. Brings characters closer for visual cohesion at large sizes. CAUTION: Can reduce readability if overused.

tight.$description: Slightly tight tracking (-0.025em). Use for: large headings (h1-h2), medium display text. Subtle tightening that improves visual density without sacrificing readability.

normal.$description: Default letter spacing (0). DEFAULT for all body text and most headings. Let the typeface's natural spacing work. Optimal for reading comprehension.

wide.$description: Slightly wide tracking (0.025em). Use for: small text (12px or less), captions that need more breathing room. Improves legibility at small sizes.

wider.$description: Wide tracking (0.05em). Use for: small caps, labels, overlines, all-caps text. Prevents all-caps text from feeling cramped. Common in: button text (sometimes), navigation labels, category headers.

widest.$description: Maximum tracking (0.1em). Use for: stylistic emphasis, spaced-out headings, decorative typography. Very pronounced spacing for special typographic treatments. Use sparingly.

xs.$description: Tight line height (1.2 / 120%). Use for: large display headings, hero text, single-line elements, buttons, badges. Text appears compact and impactful. CAUTION: Not accessible for multi-line body text. Only use for headings 24px+ or single-line UI elements. Common in: h1, hero headlines, button text, badge labels.

sm.$description: Snug line height (1.35 / 135%). Use for: smaller headings (h3-h6), subheadings, short multi-line text, compact interfaces. Tighter than body but readable for short passages. Common in: h3-h6 headings, card titles, navigation items, form labels, compact UI text.

md.$description: Normal line height (1.5 / 150%). WCAG MINIMUM for body text. Use for: standard body text, paragraphs, UI descriptions, form inputs, most readable content. Baseline for accessibility compliance. Common in: body paragraphs, descriptions, form values, help text, table cells.

lg.$description: Relaxed line height (1.65 / 165%). Use for: longer paragraphs, improved readability, wide content areas, users who need more visual separation. Better for sustained reading. Common in: article content, documentation, expanded descriptions, accessibility-focused interfaces.

xl.$description: Loose line height (1.8 / 180%). Use for: long-form prose, documentation, maximum readability, accessibility accommodations. Very generous spacing between lines. Common in: blog posts, help documentation, legal text, content prioritizing readability over density.

md.$description: Medium body text (16px). DEFAULT for paragraphs, descriptions, and primary content.

lg.$description: Large body text (18px). Use for: lead paragraphs, emphasized content, feature descriptions.

xl.$description: Extra large body text (20px). Use for: intro paragraphs, prominent content, marketing copy.
